title: Have you ever bought an album from a “one-hit-wonder” artist or band, only to find out the entire album was good? If so, what was the album? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve bought a bunch that were the only hit someone had at the time, including both Thomas Dolby and Joan Osborne (mentioned in other answers). But let me add on a few of others: Wall of Voodoo. Mexican Radio was the hit, but the album Call of the West was terrific and I’ve also bought Stan Ridgway’s solo albums.Big Country. The hit was In a Big Country, from Crossing. I could never figure out why these guys weren’t more popular.Blind Melon. No Rain was a huge hit. The rest of the eponymous album is also good, particularly Tones of Home.Chumbawumba. Tubthumping, of course. It’s not for everyone. But if you liked the hit, you’ll probably really like the rest of the album.Marshall Crenshaw. Someday, Someway was the single from his first album that was his only chart hit. But There She Goes Again and the transcendent pop song Cynical Girl make his self-titled first album one of my all-time favorites. The followup, Field Day, is just as good.Al Stewart. A lot of people only know Year of the Cat, but the rest of the album has more of his slightly quirky songs and Peter White’s terrific guitar.Animal Logic, Animal Logic. There wasn’t even really a “hit” from this — nothing cracked the Billboard charts — but There’s a Spy (In the House of Love) got a fair bit of airplay, and the album by Police drummer Stewart Copeland, jazz bass virtuoso Stanley Clarke and singer/songwriter Deborah Holland is full of terrific songs.Beth Orton, Central Reservation. The title song from this album kind of stretches the definition of “hit”, topping out at 110 in Billboard, but it’s a wonderful, ethereal, strange album. I think her voice is probably a “love it or hate it” proposition, but I love it.Camper van Beethoven, Telephone Free Landslide Victory. It had what’s been pretty much their only hit, Take the Skinheads Bowling, but there’s a lot to like here including the Eastern European/folkie Balalaika Gap and the laconic Where the Hell Is Bill?Duncan Sheik, Duncan Sheik. There was a period where it seemed like you could hear Barely Breathing everywhere you went, but Sheik never seemed to be able to capitalize on it. There’s other terrific stuff on this album in the same vein, though, particularly She Runs Away and Days Go By.Fountains of Wayne, Welcome Interstate Managers. Stacey’s Mom was full of pop hooks and a little bit subversive. The rest of the album is much the same, with a couple of more laid back tracks like Valley Winter Song and Halley’s Waitress (which is a terrific image), then there’s also Bright Future in Sales which is reminiscent of Timbuk3’s The Future’s So Bright (I Gotta Wear Shades) in sentiment, if not aurally.Ian Dury, Sex & Drugs & Rock & Roll. Dury was a real punk. He survived polio as a child, though it left him with a withered left arm and leg. A lot of his songs were, to be blunt, rather rude. Many were about sex, and not in a polite way. Hit Me With Your Rhythm Stick was the hit, but the title song and Reasons to be Cheerful (Part 3) are also great.Jill Sobule, Underdog Victorious. This is kind of a cheat. Her (minor) hit was I Kissed a Girl (much better than the Katy Perry tune), but I didn’t buy that album. I remembered the song, though, and when this came out I grabbed it. Cinnamon Park is, well, let’s say “related to” Chicago’s Saturday in the Park in a nice way. I Saw a Cop is just fun.Karla Bonoff, Karla Bonoff. This is out of the Jackson Browne/early Eagles/Linda Ronstadt California sound. She had a couple of hits later, but I picked up this album after learning that she wrote Someone to Lay Down Beside Me, that Ronstadt had a big hit with.The Nields, Gotta Get Over Greta. Best Black Dress was a modest hit and intrigued me enough to buy the album. The title track is also great, and the rest is interesting.

Marcy Playground’s self-titled album.  One night a few year’s ago my wife and I were listening the 90s station on satellite radio, as we often do, riding in the car. The song Sex and Candy came on again, which I was never really into. In fact I found it kind of annoying, even when I when I was hearing it on the the radio back in the 90s. I’m not sure why, though. Maybe it was the nonsensical lyrics or the singer’s slacker-like tone he was singing in. But that night I got to thinking about that song, I turned to my wife and mused, “I wonder what the rest of this album sounds like.” I got ahold of the album and popped it on and I was honestly blown away. The album jams from beginning to end. Okay, there are some slower, somber moments within, but ultimately most, if not all, the songs are so catchy and fun to sing out loud. John Wozniak’s vocal range is fairly attainable, so it’s easy to feel like you’re singing correctly. The opener Poppies is a fantastic 90s rock-out anthem, as is Saint Joe on the School Bus (the albums other single, which you never hear). Ancient Walls of Flowers and A Cloak of Elvenkind have me pulling out my accoustic bass to strum and sing along. And the closers The Shadows of Seattle and Vampires of New York will be stuck in your head long after the album is finished. I was so blown away by the whole of this album it changed the way I feel about the song Sex and Candy. As I now see the bigger picture I no longer find it annoying and I absolutely love that song now.

I actually heard this album before I bought it, but the one that comes to mind for me is Starring In…Standing In A Monkey Sea by A’me Lorain and the Family Affair. A’me Lorain’s big hit was called “Whole Wide World”. It doesn’t get played much on the radio these days, but it was a top ten hit in 1990, from the film True Love. Paula Abdul was a superstar at the time, and “Whole Wide World” was written and produced by Elliot Wolff, who had done the same for Abdul’s hits “Straight Up” and “Cold Hearted”. “Whole Wide World” sounded a LOT like Abdul’s hits, even sporting a male vocal part that kind of reminded me of Abdul’s “Opposites Attract” (although Wolff wasn’t involved with that one). I liked it, probably more than Abdul’s own hits, but it was a bit derivative.  I was working at a radio station in New Hampshire at the time, and we received a copy of the CD she put out. Even just looking at the cover, it didn’t quite fit with the single:  It was credited in part to a group, which the single wasn’t; she wasn’t made up to look so glamorous, and the whole thing gave a kind of psychedelic vibe. So I played it (actually, a colleague and I put it on), and I loved it. “Whole Wide World” and the follow-up single, “Follow My Heartbeat”, were Wolff’s songs and fit the Paula Abdul sound, but the rest of it definitely did not. The album was much more adventurous, diverse, and interesting than that. And FUN! Even “Whole Wide World” had a new spoken intro that put a different spin on it. Anyway, I had some trouble finding the album on vinyl, which is what I collected in those days, but I finally snagged it on a trip to Montreal. It’s been a favorite of mine ever since. For me the standout tracks are “Unique Blue Tube”, a power-pop infused song that suggests The Bangles with more of a dance beat, and the funky, Prince-influenced “Letter ‘C’ Card”. “Time You Take” is another good one, which might have been a better choice for a second single than “Follow My Heartbeat”; it was commercial and fit reasonably well with the sound of the hit, but was different enough that it wouldn’t have just seemed like another Abdul knockoff. There’s definitely an undercurrent of psychedelia through a lot of the album, as well. Unfortunately, “Follow My Heartbeat” flopped, the album didn’t chart, and as far as I know A’Me Lorain (real name Amy Trujillo) never made another record. If you’re a fan of the dance-pop of that time and enjoy a bit of diversity in the sound, I’d recommend it as worth checking out.

Yes, here are a couple from the 70’s that meet this criteria. Rick Derringer- All American Boy from 1973. This contain the huge hit, Rock and Roll Hoochie Koo (#23 on Billboard). It was his solo debut and contained several other strong songs including Teenage Queen, Cheap Tequila, The Airport Giveth, Uncomplicated and Teenage Love Affair. He is a great guitarist and this album shows it off. He had several more albums but never came close to a top 40 song again. Albert Hammond- It Never Rains In Southern California from 1973. The title song was a big hit for him (#5 on Billboard) and the rest of the album doesn’t disappoint. It’s singer-songwriter all the way and the songs are super catchy. Check out If You Gotta Break Another Heart, Brand New Day, Names Tags Numbers and Labels or The Air That I Breathe (later a hit for The Hollies). He continued to release albums, but with nowhere near the success. Thunderclap Newman- Hollywood Dream from 1970. This contained the hit Something In The Air (#37 on Billboard) which has been in many moves and a staple of FM radio since. The rest of the album contains stellar rock songs sung by “Speedy” Keene. Some of my favorites include Accidents, Hollywood Dream, Open The Door Homer and Look Around. Unfortunately, this was the only album they released.

This question was tailor-made for me on a lazy night like this. A couple of artists were already named, but different albums than I would recommend: Thomas Dolby - Aliens Ate My Buick: From the opening jazzy riffs morphing into an Our Man Flint/60s Spy cavalcade (complete with Robin Leach talk-in) of The Keys to Her Ferrari to the percolating Air Head to the undulating breeziness of The Ability to Swing and the dream-like opus, Budapest by Blimp, Dolby really showed musical chops I never knew he had. The album cover is fantastic - a take-off of 1950s drive-in B-movie schlock. To be honest, that’s the whole reason I bought the album back in 1987 because I was thinking something unusual had to be on it, what with She Blinded Me With Science being such a big hit a few years previous. Top of the list as far as this question goes, for me. Wall of Voodoo - Happy Planet: I had begun the transition from just listening to prog and hard rock when I arrived for my freshman year of college in 1984 and was indoctrinated with what was known as “college rock - a proto-Indie movement with fingers still firmly in the New Wave pie. Bands such as U2, R.E.M., The Smiths, The Church, The Replacements, et al, were part of that scene, as was W.O.V. as a hanger-on, a modest foothold on its street cred with Mexican Radio earlier in the decade. I bought this album without looking at the song list. Of particular note is the song, Joanne, which is everything fun and anachronistic about music from the 80s. The Church - Starfish: Unpredictably, it wasn’t Under the Milky Way which drove me to the music of Australia’s The Church, it was the song Reptile. The music scene where I went to college (University of Delaware) in the 1980s was, in a word, fun. One of the top covers bands on the middle of the East Coast was called Y-Not, and they covered Reptile from this album, albeit with keyboards providing the staccato riffs of The Church’s Marty Willson-Piper’s guitar. Y-Not did a high-energy version of the song, so I bought the album where it originated, and all the albums of theirs prior to that and many after. I’ve seen The Church in concert more often than any other touring band, and lead singer/bassist/founder Steve Kilbey still tours and will probably tour again after it is deemed safe to do so, both solo and with The Church. He is also a Facebook friend of mine and we have had brief conversations. Just a very chill bloke - immensely talented, intense, with an almost whimsical cynicism that I find refreshing. The whole album is packed with great songs, as are most of the others I eventually found my way to purchasing. Controversy alert: The Flaming Lips - Yoshimi Battles the Pink Robots: They can’t all be from the 80s, can they? The big hit was, of course, Do You Realize??, even though their instrumental from that album, Approaching Pavonis Mons by Balloon (Utopia Planitia), won a Grammy for Best Instrumental, the latter was largely unknown. Note: I am not including She Don’t Use Jelly from the early 1990s because I had never heard it until well after I bought this album. The whole album is such a complete confectionery treat for the ears, as if Willy Wonka had a band. They continued their tradition of convoluted song titles with In the Morning of The Magicians, Ego Tripping at the Gates of Hell, Fight Test, and what I consider the most superior aural experience on the album, Are You a Hypnotist?? Others might offer up Race for the Prize or Waitin’ On a Superman from The Soft Bulletin, but, for me, my first exposure to The ‘Lips was Do You Realize?? as I gather it was for others not hard-wired into the Indie scene as it existed at the end of the 20th Century when I basically unplugged from the increasingly vapid new music scene. (Please try to read that NOT using Comic Book Guy voice)

A couple of times, although at the time these artists caught my ear, no one considered them “one hit wonders”. I was a science-loving nerd in the early 80’s, so “She Blinded Me With Science” was right up my alley. I purchased the album, The Golden Age of Wireless, and was blown away by how good all the songs were. None of them was all that much like SBMWS, and I became a lifelong fan of Thomas Dolby. Most people have only heard his one hit, but he has a bunch of amazing albums, and almost none of it is the sort of synth-pop people associate with him. Move along a few decades or so, and there was slight, funny pop song on the radio called “One of Us”, sung by Joan Osborne. Maybe I was at a Tower Records or something, and they had a listening station for the album, Relish. Anyway, I listened to the first track, “St. Teresa”, and again, I wasn’t expecting THAT! Joan is an bluesy belter, and most of the songs sounded NOTHING like her sole radio hit, but she’s a terrific singer, and two of the guys who worked on her album and sound were Rob Hyman and Eric Bazilian (ap?) from the Hooters, who worked in a similar fashion on a seminal 80’s album, Cyndi Lauper’s She’s So Unusual! The important lesson is that many terrific musicians may only catch lightning in a bottle that one time, but just because they may not have found long-term success, it doesn’t mean they didn’t make great music!

Yes. Back in the early 90’s I was into alternative rock especially bands out of Seattle (Nirvana, Mudhoney, etc). Someone left a CD from the band “Hole” at my place. No idea how it got there but I lived with three other 20-something guys and there were always people hanging at our place. Anyways, I was staunchly against “Hole” because of lead singer Courtney Love and the caustic relationship she had with Kurt Cobain. Nothing personal with her- but she got a lot of the blame for Kurts demise whether true or not. I also thought she probably got a record deal because of her relationship with Cobain. It was a completely unfair and unfounded prejudice against her. I drove a car with a CD player- this is pre-internet and cell phone- and on a road trip it was easy to lose radio station signals. I couldn’t find my usual thick folder of CDs in the car except one- the CD/album “Live Through This” by Hole. With nothing else to listen to, I decided to give it a try. Turned out to be a an amazing rock album. Great songs from start to finish. I loved it. Music is a very personal taste but for me, this album was tight. I was stunned and I gained a new respect for Courtney Love’s musical talent and still have Hole in my Spotify 90’s rotation.

The Swedish group Whale were a one-hit wonder on the Modern Rock charts with “Hobo Humpin’ Slobo Babe,” mainly based on a video that ended up in a Beavis and Butthead episode. But the rest of their album We Care is really good too. Their lead singer was really sexy in an off-the-wall way, and they had a weird sound that no other band could really replicate.   Pete Rock and C.L. Smooth made a classic hip hop one-hit wonder with “They Reminisce Over You (T.R.O.Y.),” but the rest of the album, Mecca and the Soul Brother, is really tight with no filler. I love the line in “The Basement”: “I make music for my peoples./I get large like the Beatles.” If you like jazzier 1990s hip hop like A Tribe Called Quest, you’re in for a treat with Mecca and the Soul Brother.   Blue Cheer had a one-hit wonder back in 1968 with a psychedelicized version of Eddie Cochran’s “Summertime Blues,” but the album it belongs to, Vincebus Eruptum, is just as good. My copy is some scratchy copy I found in a bargain bin for $3.98, but you literally can’t hear any scratches, because the record is just so frickin’ loud! They were a psychedelic San Francisco band, but they had a hard biker edge to them. They were even managed by a Hell’s Angel who was only known by the name Gut. Their version of “Summertime Blues” hit #14 on the charts, winning them a slot on American Bandstand, but they got permanently banned after their only appearance after Dick Clark caught them smoking a bowl of hashish in their dressing room. If you listen to Vincebus Eruptum, you can hear both elements of a grunge and heavy metal, neither of which really existed at the time.   Bubble Puppy was the most commercially successful of all those crazy Austin, Texas psych bands that were in the same scene as The 13th Floor Elevators, even though they only had one Top 20 hit with “Hot Smoke and Sassafras.” On the album cover of A Gathering of Promises, they look like they fled stoned from a Renaissance Faire, but the album shows they know how to rock.   Love is no mere one-hit wonder to me. They’re one of my favorite bands of all time, but they technically only have one Top Forty hit, “Seven and Seven Is,” off the album Da Capo. Side 2 is a side long jam, but I like it, and the rest of the album is good, not just the hit. The track “She Comes In Colours” is especially influential, because it conceptually inspired the Rolling Stones, “She’s a Rainbow” and Madonna ripped off the melody for “Beautiful Stranger.”

Lots of them… But for the sake of brevity I’ll just mention this one. It blew me away in 1980 and I still follow this guy, though the closest he’s come to a hit since was “Hail, Hail, Rock ‘n’ Roll” in 1991. But his 6th album produced a Billboard Top 100 single in the U.S. He never got close before or since. He’s still recording genius albums, but most of you haven't heard of him. I’m talking about Garland Jeffreys. Born in Sheepshead Bay, BK, NY, of a truly American heritage, African-American and Puerto Rican, and plays a mix of Rock ’n’ Roll, Blues, R&B, Soul, Reggae and, at that time, Alternative/Punk. The album that made me a fan for life was this one: Garland Jeffreys: Escape Artist (1980)  Just keep playing the album in order….you’ll get it. The big hit was a remake of a ? & The Mysterious hit, “96 Tears”, but it was far from the best song on the album.

Actually I bought an album labeled jerry lee lewis and friends. The friend turned out to be elvis but his name is not on the album as it was recorded in a studio that he did have a contract with so they couldn’t release it under his name. It’s all duets and you wish that jerry lee would be quite so you can hear elvis better.

The Georgia Satellites and their self-named debut album. Everyone knows “Keep Your Hands To Yourself”, but they were actually a really outstanding Southern Rock outfit. Kind of reminded me of Lynyrd Skynyrd without sounding a whole lot like them. Nearly every song on that debut album is great, especially Battleship Chains, their cover of Every Picture Tells A Story, Nights Of Mystery, Railroad Steel, and since I’m a Firebird aficionado, of course Red Light (“That Firebird flew like it just grew wings”). Saw them open for Bob Seger that summer, and they honestly blew him off the stage. One of the only times I’d seen a headliner rush to take the stage after the opening act - he didn’t give them a full minute when they left regardless of the fact that the auditorium was screaming for an encore. Besides being an overall solid band, Dan Baird is a talented songwriter. I always figured his solo career fizzled mostly because he’s not the handsomest guy at a time when that started to be the determining factor. He did have a solo hit with “I Love You Period”, but that was pretty much it.

A few albums come to mind…. first was Golden Earring’s “Moontan” album with the original ‘Radar Love’. Of course they didn't remain a one-hit artist and were actually a bigger act in their homeland Holand but unheard of here in the states at the time. The album to this day remains one of the best album start to finish. The ‘Yes’ album “Fragile” was just amazing…I had heard them before and I'd enjoyed them but when ‘Roundabout’ hit the airwaves I went right out to get the record and well — we all pretty much know their history from that point on. The “Year of the Cat” album by Al Stuart was another one I felt that way about. Some great songs and fantastic guitar work by Peter White. Also, the Peter Schilling album “Error in the System” that had the song ‘Coming Home’ (Major Tom) on it. I thought it and his next album were full of great songs. And there was the “Orinoco Flow” by Enya… I knew her from her work with ‘Clannad’ but this album literally introduced a whole new music to the public at large. Some my love it, some hate it but it was a force that couldn't be denied nor expected when it came out. Now there have been several albums that just turned out to be great buys but for ones that were from supposed one-hit artists, these were great finds of course these didn't necessarily remains one hit artist.

I have too many to name but an obvious one is the 1976, self named “Wild Cherry” album. That’s the band who had the big #1 hit “Play That Funky Music”. The album isn't Disco, it’s blues & funk. In fact, they kind of rival The Commodore at their funkiest. No other hits but their version of “I Feel Sanctified” is awesome. P. S. - To the one who said AL Stewart was a one hit wonder. He actually had 4 hits between 1976 and 1980. ☺️ Year Of The Cat, Time Passages, Song On The Radio and Midnight Rocks. These reached -(in order in the U S.) : #8, #7, #24 and #29, on the Hot 100. AL Stewart almost had a fifth top 40 hit with “On The Border” but it stopped at #42. Also from ‘The Year Of The Cat’ LP. So really, his biggest hit is “Time Passages.“ Weird fact : Before ‘Cat’ in 1976 and after his last hit in 1980, None of Al’s singles made the Hot 100 at AL / or ever again.

How else do you become a fan? Based on this song, about which there was a rumor that it was the Beatles:  I bought the whole album:  Which was good, then I bought the follow up  Which blew me away There was also this little song that was cut down to a few minutes for radio play  Which led me to buy this album  Which was all right, then this one  Which was absolutely superb, then this one  Which was also really good, then this one  Which was different, but also really good

I have many albums that I bought because I heard one song on the radio that I liked, only to find that the entire album was wonderful. But the only one that qualifies as a one-hit-wonder is Partners In Crime, by Rupert Holmes. Everyone knows Escape (The Pina Colada Song), and some may even be familiar with Him, which wasn’t a huge hit, though I do hear it from time to time. But the rest of the album is filled with gems that contain great lyrics and memorable music. I especially love Lunch Hour, Drop It, Answering Machine, Get Outta Yourself, and The People That You Never Get To Love. In fact, there isn’t a bad song on either side, and I will gladly listen to it over and over. Rupert Holmes has a great sense of humor that comes through in many of his songs, while others are wistful and a little sad. But the whole album is worth a listen, and I highly recommend it.

I’m not sure if he counts as a “one-hit wonder;” maybe a two-hit wonder, as a solo artist. But, and if you’re not already sick of “Escape (The Pina Colada Song),” or his follow-up “Him,” Rupert Holmes’ album Partners In Crime is a favorite of mine. Yes, it’s very dated. Originally released in 1979, the cover photographer did his best to try and make Rupert look like John Ritter of the then-huge hit TV sitcom Three’s Company, and some of the subject matter of various songs, which might have been considered cutting-edge then, is blasé now. Nevertheless, IMHO almost every song has a great melody, witty lyrics, is memorable, and thankfully, not as cutesy as the album’s biggest hit. Plus, anyone who wears glasses will automatically love “Nearsighted.” I recommend it to everyone.

Way back in the day, I picked up the Blues Image album (yes, album) for ‘Ride, Captain Ride,’ and found the rest was very good also. They were actually a blues/rock band, and their members went on to join prominent bands. “[Manuel "Manny"] Bertematti later played and recorded with New Cactus Band and toured with Iron Butterfly, Chi Coltrane, and Bobby Womack. [Mike] Pinera also played with Iron Butterfly, New Cactus Band, Ramatam, and Alice Cooper. [Frank ‘Skip’] Konte joined Three Dog Night, and [Joe] Lala played with Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young. Lala's percussion work also figures prominently on the Stephen Stills/Chris Hillman led group, Manassas. [Kent] Henry played lead guitar with Steppenwolf prior to their break-up in 1972.”

I remember hearing “You Get What You Give” in a Camelot music store in Daytona beach back in 1998. I asked the cute girl working behind the counter if she knew who the band was. Not only did she know, she was a fan and she was going to see them live in Orlando in a few days—they were called The New Radicals. I decided to buy the album as an excuse to chat up the girl some more. Turns out, she had a boyfriend. But I took the album home and listened to it a few times. It was fantastic—the singer’s voice sounded like a young Mick Jagger and all of the songs were impeccably written and performed. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DL7-CKirWZE

Probably my favorite which I listen to at least once a month: The Refreshments “Fizzy, Fuzzy, Big and Buzzy”. Their big hit was “Banditos” in 1996 and they had one other single from the album that did okay on the alternative charts. This entire album (except for one song that is tolerable) is great. Most of the songs are in the storyteller-style and are great for sky road trip. Besides “Banditos” their other big hit is the theme song to “King of the Hill”. While the band has broken up, the lead singer and drummer still tour as Roger Clyne and the Peacemakers. They’re a great live act playing new songs as well as Refreshments hits.

I rarely bought singles so if I heard a song I liked I would invariably buy the CD album it was from. A lot of times that meant I had a whole album with only one good track. A couple of exceptions: New Radicals - Maybe You’ve Been Brainwashed Too I really love this album. You Get What You Give was the single but the rest of the songs are just as good. The core of the band was Gregg Alexander and Danielle Brisebois (check out her albums too) and from what I understand they didn’t care for the grind of touring and promotion, hence there being no more albums. Cake - Fashion Nugget The hits were The Distance and their cover of I Will Survive and that’s why I got it. Really enjoyed the rest of it (and Cake’s other albums)

I'm not proud of this, but back when “Jagged Little Pill" came out, I thought the song “All I Really Want” was catchy in a “sexy, throwed - off bitch" kinda way. So I got the CD….wore it thin……(hangs head sheepishly) then went to her show….with my wife….found ourselves in a sea of 15 year old girls that were anxiously awaiting the moment they could - as one - chime in on their favorite line in “You oughtta know"…(all together now!) Are you thinking of me when you FUCK HER? Awkward indeed. So, yeah Alanis was an unsettling attraction and journey I can't un-see. Cheers

There was a British band called Haircut 100, and their 1981 debut album “Pelican West” had two hit singles, “Favorite Shirts” and “Love Plus One”. They are generally classified as “new wave”, but their haircuts were nothing unusual, and they had no synths. What the band — five very white lads and one black lad, all very British in their heavy wool sweaters — had, was some really bright tropical-sounding funk, with lots of brass, percussion, wacka-wacka-wacka guitar that would put Nile Rodgers to shame, and clever lyrics. The singer/guitarist and leader Nick Heyward had some successful solo albums, and the band without him put out a second album, but it flopped, and that was it for Haircut. The album also exposed me to an Irish expression — “What’s the craic?” — whose meaning (and spelling) I did not learn until 30 years later. It is still one of my favorite albums and I listen to it now and again, especially when springtime rolls around.

Had that a few times, including the first one I ever bought - “The Age of Plastic” by The Buggles. Got it for “Video Killed the Radio Star”, but there’s not a a bad song on it (I’m really fond of “Elstree” and “Clean, Clean”). Others include Soul Asylum’s “Grave Dancer’s Union” (for “Runaway Train”, a modest hit here - rest of the album is pretty decent), Re-Flex’s “The Politics of Dancing” (had the eponymous single on a compilation album for years before Cherry Red finally re-issued its parent album - top notch stuff, particularly “Praying to the Beat” and “Hit Line”) and Alannah Myles’ eponymous debut album (for “Black Velvet”, but “Kick Start My Heart”, “Rock This Joint” and “Love Is” are also pretty good).

Back in 2004 my roommate was listening to music on one of those cable TV music channels in the living room and I was in my room just doing nothing. This song came on and after a minute or two I was like, ‘What is this! It’s amazing!’ He looked at the description on the TV and hollered back to me. Within five minutes I was on Amazon in my room and had just bought the album. I got it a few days later and must have listened to it hundreds of times over the years. The song: One Big Holiday from My Morning Jacket on the album It Still Moves

A few albums from the late '80s come to mind:The Sidewinders had a minor hit with the song 'Witch Doctor'. I bought the album of the same name - it is terrific. Still play it regularly.The band Dreams so Real, out of Athens, Georgia had a minor hit with 'Rough Night in Jericho' (also the name of the album). Really good album. They were panned as an 'R.E.M. soundalike' by some critics, but as an R.E.M. fan I can attest to that being a load of shit. Very good band, very good album.The Insiders had a hit with 'Ghost on the Beach'. The whole album is very listenable with a few real gems.

Yes Player (1977) the group famous for the hit Baby Come Back, their self titled debut album was filled with great songs like the blue eyed soul Hall and Oates sound of Love is Where You Find It, This Time Im in it for Love or Commodores/Wild Cherry hard funk jams like Movin Up as well as some Steely Dan in Come on Out and Kenny Loggins in Goodbye That's all I ever heard and whole lotta Ambrosia Foreigner pop rock. Shame they never pursued this eclectic funky soul direction in later albums they became another corporate rock band.

I first heard September Gurls on a friend’s mixtape, and the rest is … as the say … history, as Big Star influenced much of my musical experience after that. On the same tape was a track from “A Scandal in Bohemia” - the Jazz Butcher. To this day, I love this album. So many great, irreverent tracks. Check out “Just Like Betty Page”.

American Pie. I would say Don McClean is basically only known for this hit. I don’t know about others that may have been a hit as I don’t follow music that intensely. In any case I really really like Starry Starry Night even more than American Pie. Other songs were really good too though I can’t name them offhand, again, not that involved.

Have you ever bought an album from a “one-hit-wonder” artist or band, only to find out the entire album was good? If so, what was the album? Norman Greenbaum: Spirit In the Sky. The rest of the album was much different than the title track. But still great stuff. Folkish, kind of in the same spirit as Loudon Wainright III.

The Buggles had one of the first videos I'd ever seen in 1980, “Video Killed the Radio Star”. And most people only remember the Buggles for that one song, but “The Age of Plastic” is still to this day one of my favorite albums, which I consider a forgotten gem. The Age of Plastic (Full Album with Bonus Tracks) - YouTube

I always liked Show Me Heaven by Maria McKee so I bought her self titled solo debut album, and her first two Lone Justice albums, which didn’t have this song on them, and I thought they were even better in places.
In America, the Small Faces are one hit wonders, known only for the silly “Itchycoo Park.” But they were a truly great band, and “Ogden’s Nut Gone Flake” is a brilliant album.

At the time I did not know they would be one hit wonders. I bought “big lad in the windmill” the first album by It Bites on the back of the single. It turned out to be their only hit - as the British turned away from prog pop. They were a good band and I have other albums of theirs. As it happens they were at school with my brother-in-law. But he was inot Morrisey not neo-prog.

Marcy Playground’s self-titled album. What an underrated piece of music. Sex and Candy was the big hit and it’s a good song, but it’s also got St. Joe on the School Bus, Poppies, Sherry Fraser, and Cloak of Elvenkind. It’s like laid back Nirvana.

Far more frequently I bought the album that contained the hit, and found that I’d have been better off buying the single. Another mistake was too frequently buying the follow-on album rather than the one with the hit I’d heard a lot.
I happened upon this album while doing random “if you like this” follow-up some time ago. The entire album has held up for me, even though some of the songs sound derivative of a variety of bands.

Not really a one hit wonder, but I bought the Smashing Pumpkins Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness album for two songs. I really liked Tonight Tonight and Bullet with Butterfly Wings. I had no idea what the rest of the album was like. It was the first album I ever bought where I like every single song, and it had a lot of songs!

The Modulations, several charting singles, but only one LP, “It’s Rough Out Here”, from 1975. Good to have it on vinyl. Their Soul Train appearance, “Worth Your Weight in Gold”:  One of their others, “I’m Hopelessly in Love” with the album cover:
“The Age of Plastic” by The Buggles is a magnificent album that contains their one mega-hit, “Video Killed the Radio Star.” Every song on it could've been a big hit.
There’s no such thing.It’s a title made up by lazy arsed ‘music journalists’.Like saying ‘the devil is in the detail’ but about music.
